column2: Wearing-off symptoms during standard and extended natalizumab dosing intervals: Experiences from the COVID-19 pandemic

column2: Commentary Extended interval dosing of natalizumab: More evidence in support
column6: The paper evaluates extended interval dosing (EID) of natalizumab versus standard interval dosing (SID) in adults with multiple sclerosis (MS), assessing outcomes such as disease activity, relapse rates, and safety (including PML risk). It meets all PICO criteria: population (adults), intervention (natalizumab, SID/EID), comparison (SID vs EID), and outcomes (MS).

column2: LETTER TO THE EDITORS Intense immunosuppression for the treatment of an immune reconstitution inﬂammatory syndrome-like exacerbation after natalizumab withdrawal: a case report
column6: The paper focuses on a case of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) following natalizumab withdrawal in an adult with multiple sclerosis (MS), and describes treatment with intense immunosuppression (cyclophosphamide and rituximab). This matches the population (adults), intervention (natalizumab, SID/EID), and outcomes (MS) criteria. Exclusions for ocrelizumab and fingolimod are not violated.
